citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the inspection in the sheep pasture, a white, female domestic sheep was observed to be severely limping on her
front right leg. When encouraged to walk, the ewe would touch her right front toes to the ground but not bear weight on
the leg. The facility representatives were unaware of the abnormal gait of the animal until pointed out by the inspector.
The attending veterinarian had not been notified of the abnormal condition of the sheep and veterinary care has not been
provided to evaluate the sheep's leg. Daily observation of all animals shall be made to assess their health and well-being
and promptly identify injuries, disease, and other medical conditions. Untreated injuries, infections, and other conditions
can be painful and cause suffering to the animal. The female sheep must be evaluated by a veterinarian and any
prescribed treatments and care must be followed.
***To be corrected by: 5:00pm CST on 8/21/24 or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first.

The licensee is lacking an inventory record that accurately reflects the animals currently on hand. The most up-to-date
version does not include all youngstock born or hatched on premises or animals recently received. Additionally, complete
acquisition and disposition records need to be kept for all animals and made available to APHIS personnel upon request.
APHIS Form 7005 shall be used for acquisition of cats. Inventory and associated records allow Animal Care officials to
track movements and whereabouts of the animals. Ensure that a current inventory and complete acquisition and
disposition information is maintained for animals on hand, any offspring born or hatched on premises, and animals sold,
transferred, or dead.

The facility recently received guinea pigs that were being exhibited and housed in outdoor facilities. Guinea pigs shall not
be housed in outdoor facilities unless such facilities are located in an appropriate climate and prior approval for such
outdoor housing is obtained from the Deputy Administrator. Outdoor housing does not adequately protect the guinea pigs
from severe temperature changes and adverse environmental conditions. Correct by ensuring that guinea pigs are moved
to adequate indoor facilities.
***Note: This was corrected prior to the exit interview as facility representatives moved the 3 guinea pigs from their
outdoor exhibit area to an indoor exhibit area.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection was conducted with facility representatives and
the exit briefing was conducted with the applicant.
Correct the direct non-compliance by 5:00 pm CST on 8/21/24 or prior to the next re-license inspection, whichever comes
first. All non-compliant items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/21/24 or the applicant will forfeit
the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. An unannounced inspection to reinspect for
the direct non-compliance may be conducted prior to your next licensing inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During the inspection in the sheep pasture, a white, female domestic sheep was observed to be severely limping on her 
front right leg. When encouraged to walk, the ewe would touch her right front toes to the ground but not bear weight on 
the leg. The facility representatives were unaware of the abnormal gait of the animal until pointed out by the inspector. 
The attending veterinarian had not been notified of the abnormal condition of the sheep and veterinary care has not been 
provided to evaluate the sheep's leg. Daily observation of all animals shall be made to assess their health and well-being 
and promptly identify injuries, disease, and other medical conditions. Untreated injuries, infections, and other conditions 
can be painful and cause suffering to the animal. The female sheep must be evaluated by a veterinarian and any 
prescribed treatments and care must be followed.  
 
***To be corrected by: 5:00pm CST on 8/21/24 or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first. 
2.75 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee is lacking an inventory record that accurately reflects the animals currently on hand. The most up-to-date 
version does not include all youngstock born or hatched on premises or animals recently received. Additionally, complete 
acquisition and disposition records need to be kept for all animals and made available to APHIS personnel upon request. 
APHIS Form 7005 shall be used for acquisition of cats. Inventory and associated records allow Animal Care officials to 
track movements and whereabouts of the animals. Ensure that a current inventory and complete acquisition and 
disposition information is maintained for animals on hand, any offspring born or hatched on premises, and animals sold, 
transferred, or dead. 
3.27(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility recently received guinea pigs that were being exhibited and housed in outdoor facilities. Guinea pigs shall not 
be housed in outdoor facilities unless such facilities are located in an appropriate climate and prior approval for such 
outdoor housing is obtained from the Deputy Administrator. Outdoor housing does not adequately protect the guinea pigs 
from severe temperature changes and adverse environmental conditions. Correct by ensuring that guinea pigs are moved 
to adequate indoor facilities.

***Note: This was corrected prior to the exit interview as facility representatives moved the 3 guinea pigs from their 
outdoor exhibit area to an indoor exhibit area. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection was conducted with facility representatives and 
the exit briefing was conducted with the applicant. 
 
Correct the direct non-compliance by 5:00 pm CST on 8/21/24 or prior to the next re-license inspection, whichever comes 
first. All non-compliant items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/21/24 or the applicant will forfeit 
the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply.  
 
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. An unannounced inspection to reinspect for 
the direct non-compliance may be conducted prior to your next licensing inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a 
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
